tossups.question: A characteristic of cancer aggression is the upregulation of “core serum response” genes in these cells. EPC’s are more effectively recruited by the “carcinoma-associated” variant of these cells. Reticular cells are specialized versions of these cells that help support naive T cells. They’re not stem cells, but NIH 3T3 cells and “mouse embryonic [these cells]” are two types of them commonly used in cell (*) culture. Human cells of this type are the most common feeder layer for growing stem cells. When these cells express smooth muscle actin they are prefixed ‘myo-’. Platelets release compounds like TGF-beta and PDGF to attract and activate these cells in the wound-healing response. For 10 points, name these cells that secrete collagen and synthesize the extracellular matrix.
tossups.answer: fibroblast(s) [accept myofibroblast or carcinoma-associated fibroblast; prompt on CAF]

tossups.question: Locations created during this conflict were excoriated by Henry Campbell-Bannerman in the question “when is a war not a war?” following a scorched earth campaign against homesteads. During this conflict, Sarah Wilson became one of the first female war correspondents when reporting on a siege involving fake landmines and fake barbed wire. Floris Visser was killed during this conflict by a man who became an Australian national hero, (*) Breaker Morant. Emily Hobhouse reported on the conditions of concentration camps created during this war. Robert Baden-Powell gained fame for his victory at the Siege of Mafeking during this conflict. For 10 points, name this conflict, which saw the complete defeat of Dutch forces in South Africa.
tossups.answer: Second Boer War [prompt on Boer Wars; do NOT accept “First Boer War”]

tossups.question: This thinker's theodicy dismisses the problem of evil by saying "if God is wiser than we, his judgments must differ from ours on many things." In a book with chapters such as "The Naturalist and the Supernaturalist" and "The Self-Contradiction of the Naturalist," this thinker argued that belief in the title concept is not incompatible with historical reality. In addition to writing The Problem of Pain and Miracles, this thinker compared theology to the use of a map in a landmark work of (*) apologetics. This thinker's main theological work argues that Jesus must have been a liar, a lunatic, or God in his namesake Trilemma. For 10 points, name this lay theologian who wrote Mere Christianity, as well as religious novels such as The Screwtape Letters and The Chronicles of Narnia.
tossups.answer: C.S. Lewis [or Clive Staples Lewis]

tossups.question: A butcher and a farrier argue in this novel over whether or not a cow was a red Durham breed. The protagonist of this novel repeats “God will clear me” at a trial where he is found guilty in part due to the discovery of a knife in a bureau. In this novel, the body of a character who went missing after attempting to sell the horse Wildfire is found at the bottom of the (*) stone pits. Nancy Lammeter marries a character in this novel whose opium-addicted secret wife freezes to death. After he is robbed of his gold, the title character of this novel adopts the child Eppie, who is secretly the daughter of Godfrey Cass. For 10 points, name this novel named for a “Weaver of Raveloe,” written by George Eliot.

tossups.question: This person provided choreography for a work that ends with Andrew II of Hungary blessing the marriage of Raymonda and Jean de Brienne. This choreographer created four revivals of the final work he had performed as a dancer, in which the pirate Conrad rescues his enslaved lover Medora. tossups.question: One ethnicity from the northern portion of this country is divided into "hard" and "soft" types depending on the dialect they speak. In addition to the Kankanaey, this country is home to a group of lowland people called the Bukidnon, which means"of the mountains" This country's indigenous people include the Lumad and the Igorot, whose ancestors in the (*) Ifugao region built the Banaue rice terraces. This country is home to the isolated Tasaday people, which were previously believed to be a hoax created to generate tourism. The ongoing Moro conflict in this country is centered on it's southern island of Mindanao. For 10 points, name this southeast Asian island nation home to the island of Luzon, with capital Manilla.
tossups.answer: The Philippines

tossups.question: A self-assembled film of DNA on a carbon electrode is one highly effective technique for the voltammetric isolation of this element. High pressure lamps with vapors of this element are used to drive photochemical reactions, such as the Barton reaction. The potassium tetraiodo salt of this element is used to test for ammonia and is known as (*) Nessler's reagent. Sodium borohydride and this element’s acetate are used in a reaction that converts alkenes to alcohols. Minamata disease is caused by poisoning with this element. In 1997, Dartmouth chemist Karen Wetterhahn died from exposure to the dimethyl form of this element, which is found naturally with sulfur in the ore cinnabar. For 10 points, name this silvery liquid metal.
tossups.answer: mercury [accept Hg or hydrargyrum or quicksilver; accept dimethyl mercury]

tossups.question: William Arrowsmith wrote that this play’s central characters were meant to represent phalluses. In this play, the gibberish line “Nabaisatreu” is uttered by the pagan god Triballus. A religious ceremony in this play is interrupted by a poet, an oracle-monger, and the astronomer Meton, who are all attacked and driven out. A character in this play convinces Heracles to return Zeus’ sceptre to him and allow him to marry (*) Basileia. After wandering away from Athens at the start of this play, two characters find Tereus, who turned himself into a hoopoe (“HOO-pow”). tossups.question: Rainald of Dassel’s translation of the word beneficium sparked tensions between Roland of Siena and a ruler of this name. Pietro della Vigna advised a ruler of this name and wrote the Constitutions of Melfi for him. Despite being excommunicated by Gregory IX, a ruler of this name acquired Jerusalem through diplomatic dealings with Sultan al-Kamil during the (*) Sixth Crusade. A ruler of this name is said to be sleeping in the Kyffhauser mountains. That ruler of this name was defeated at Legnano by the Lombard League. A ruler of this name drowned in the Saleph River due to his heavy armor during the Third Crusade. For 10 points, give this regnal name of a Holy Roman Emperor nicknamed “red beard”.

tossups.question: This artist’s “overlooked radicalism” is discussed in a 2018 essay by Griselda Pollock, who is credited with authoring one of the earliest feminist studies on this artist. This artist was commissioned to paint a now lost companion piece to Mary MacMonnies’ mural “Primitive Woman” for the 1893 World’s Fair. This artist’s sister, Lydia, is among the many elegantly dressed women sitting in (*) “loges” that this artist depicted later in life. A man and wife ride in a sailboat with their pink gown-wearing child in another work by this artist. The protagonist of a novel has one instance of a recurring toothache after thinking about a portrait of a character based on this man hanging above his bed. In a poem, this person is described as “ringed with the scum of chicken-necked bosses” and having “huge laughing cockroaches on his top lip.” This subject of an (*) “epigram” by Osip Mandelstam was fictionalized as Number One in Arthur Koestler’s novel Darkness at Noon. tossups.question: Description Acceptable. A tell-all by Rebecca Reed detailing punishment by forced corset-wearing furthered this sentiment, leading to the burning of a building in Charlestown in 1834. A presidential candidate tried to quiet this sentiment by referencing the lack of any “test at the Alamo” when describing the “kind of America” that the speaker’s brother died for in Europe. In the second word of a phrase spoken at the 1884 RNC, Samuel Burchard expressed this (*) sentiment. Crocodiles menacingly approach schoolchildren in a Thomas Nast cartoon expressing this sentiment. tossups.question: Nitrogen-vacancy centers in this material are surrounded by localized clusters of hyperfine-coupled nuclear spins in a quantum processor capable of producing long-lived qubits. “Hydrogen-terminated” surfaces of this material exhibit p-type surface conductivity, making it a candidate for high charge carrier mobility FETs. A synthesis capsule is at the center of a BARS apparatus for manufacturing this material. Culets hold a sample between two opposing pieces of this material in an (*) anvil cell for testing material responses to extreme pressure. The abbreviation HPHT is given to synthetic examples of this material created using high pressure and high temperature. The decline of these entities has been turned into the "new chic" according to a book by Neil Smith. tossups.question: The Phoenician technique of almadraba was commonly used for this activity in Islamic Spain. A 1998 book by Mark Kurlansky argued that this activity was responsible for the European discovery of the Americas. One traditional form of this activity involves participants standing on cross shaped poles called petta. Another traditional type of this activity practiced in East Asia involves tying a noose around the neck of a (*) cormorant. A type of this activity from the American south that is done entirely by hand is known as noodling. Dredging and trawling are methods used in the commercial form of this activity, which has been blamed for decreasing biodiversity in the oceans. tossups.question: One philosopher from this country defended his legal philosophy with the phrase "The law is an expression of love for the people." Another philosopher from this country argued against elaborate funerals and prolonged mourning as contradictions to the notion of frugality. That philosopher from this country also created a three-pronged test for doctrinal validity. Another philosopher from this country formulated the paradox, "a white (*) horse is not a horse" and was a member of the school of names. Another philosopher from this country formulated the concepts of humanity and ritual, or ren and li, in The Analects. For 10 points, name this home country of Mozi, Gongsun Long, and Confucius.

tossups.question: These people were massacred after a man raised an Alcantara cross to his chest, resulting in the hanging of Queen Anacaona. Stories involving these people’s zemis spirits were documented by Ramon Pane. Nicolas de Ovando killed hundreds of these people along with a man who believed he could subjugate them with fifty soldiers, writing that they would make good (*) slaves. Enriquillo and Hatuey resisted conquest as caciques of these people, though they were eventually made the first victims of the encomienda system. These people constantly warred with the Caribs of the Lesser Antilles. For 10 points, name this indigenous people of Hispaniola that was almost entirely exterminated after the arrival of Christopher Columbus.
tossups.answer: Taino [or Arawak]

tossups.question: This many instruments play in the Praise to the Immortality of Jesus movement of one composition. This is the number of distinct voices used in Arvo Pärt’s tintinnabuli style. This number of instruments play open D’s at the beginning of Transfigured Night. Charles Ives included The Unanswered Question in a group of this many (*) Contemplations. The Adagio for Strings is taken from this number movement of Barber’s String Quartet in B minor. A movement from Bartok’s Concerto for Orchestra splits instruments into groups of this size in a namesake “game.” For 10 points, the slow movement of string quartets is often what movement number, which is also the number of violins in a standard string quartet?

tossups.question: In one novel, Darrell hangs himself after a character of this ethnicity refuses to leave her husband, the wheelchair-bound Bud. Another character of this ethnicity spends his 27th birthday at a lake house with the high-class Ratliff family. A character of this ethnicity is rescued from a (*) train crash after reaching for his copy of “The Overcoat,” leading him to name his son Gogol. A boy with this ethnicity defines the title word as “loving someone you don’t know” in the story “Sexy,” which is found in the collection Interpreter of Maladies. A protocol used for calculating this value sorts data into strata and then determines a final value using a modified Marzullo's Algorithm. In Linux, the command ls -u (“L, S, hyphen, U”) will return data related to this value. In C++, it is typical to use this value as a (*) seed for the s-rand random number generator. NASA believes that a malfunction in the computational process for determining this value caused the failure of its Deep Impact probe. bonuses.leadin: This ruler legendarily ordered his first wife, Elisabeth of Vendome, to be burnt at the stake over accusations of adultery. For 10 points each:

Martel [accept “the hammer”; accept Geoffroy Martel or Charles Martel]
parts: Name this early count of Anjou who pioneered a strategy of coupling territorial expansion with the creation of an extensive network of defensive fortifications, monasteries, and abbeys.

Fulk Nerra is celebrated as one of the most prominent builders of these buildings in all of medieval Europe, ordering the construction of over 100 of these fortified residences throughout the Loire valley during his reign.

Fulk Nerra’s son and successor, Geoffrey II of Anjou, received this epithet for his aggressively expansionist military policies. An earlier French leader earned this epithet for his defeat of Abd-ar-Rahman.
answers_formatted: Fulk Nerra [or Fulk III of Anjou or Foulque Nerra or Fulk the Black; prompt on Fulk of Anjou or Nerra alone]

bonuses.leadin: In this religious tradition, the soul may be divided into hun and po, which leave the body after death and remain in the corpse respectively. For 10 points each:
answers: Chinese folk religion [or Zhongguo minjian xinyang; accept any answer indicating the traditional religious beliefs of China]
parts: Name this general religious tradition, which most commonly worships heaven as Shangdi or Tian. This religious tradition is frequently described as a blend of Daoist, Confucian, and Buddhist ideas. A description is acceptable.

This agricultural deity is one of the most popular deities in Chinese folk religion. This "First Deity of the Five Grains" is held to have discovered tea when leaves blew into his cup and is often combined with the Flame Emperor.

This other deity from Chinese folk religion is held to be the last of the Three Sovereigns or the first of the Five Emperors. This figure is revered as the founder of Chinese civilization and is believed to have been king during the creation of Chinese writing..
answers_formatted: Chinese folk religion [or Zhongguo minjian xinyang; accept any answer indicating the traditional religious beliefs of China]
acceptable: any answer indicating the traditional religious beliefs of China

bonuses.leadin: Maurice Jarre’s score to this film plays as Christiane frees dogs and doves used for experiments. For 10 points each:

parts: Name this 1960 French film by George Franju, a pioneering early horror movie. After a car accident in this film, a plastic surgeon kidnaps women and takes their body parts to restore his daughter’s appearance.
The creepy mask in Eyes Without a Face was an inspiration for the one worn by the serial killer Michael Myers, who murdered his sister on the title holiday in this horror film.

George Franju was a fan of an earlier horror film about a scientist who merges with one of these animals when one enters his teleportation device. David Cronenberg remade that movie titled for this animal with Jeff Goldblum as the scientist.

bonuses.leadin: Due to the success of this play, its author stayed in a first-class hotel room where he accidentally poured chocolate sauce on his steak, thinking it was gravy. For 10 points each:

poker [accept The Poker Game; accept seven-card stud; prompt on cards]
parts: Name this play whose popularity overwhelmed its author, according to the essay “The Catastrophe of Success.”
This playwright wrote “The Catastrophe of Success” three years after the Chicago opening of The Glass Menagerie and four days before the premiere of A Streetcar Named Desire.

In “The Catastrophe of Success,” Williams mentions the original title for A Streetcar Named Desire, which references this activity. At the end of the play, Stanley, Mitch, and others play this game after Stella leaves.

bonuses.leadin: In liquid state theory, this two-word term refers to the region of space that is inaccessible to other molecules in a system due to the presence of the first molecule. For 10 points each:
answers: entropy [accept loop entropy or Wang-Uhlenbeck entropy]
Gibbs free energy [prompt on free energy]
parts: Name this two-word term that is also used in polymer chemistry to describe the concept that one part of a long molecule can’t occupy the same space as another part of the same molecule, as most ideal chain theories assume.

When two polymer residues are brought close together, excluded volume effects largely account for the loss in this quantity. In one formula, this quantity equals K-sub-B times the natural log of the number of microstates.

The concept of the excluded volume was first applied to polymers by Paul Flory. Flory co-names a model of polymer solutions with Maurice Huggins that adds a factor, chi, to the equation for this quantity, which is typically calculated as “H minus T times S”.

bonuses.leadin: During this man’s HUAC testimony, he stated that “in Russia, I felt for the first time that I was a human being”. For 10 points each:

Robeson was brought before HUAC after the testimony of this other civil rights figure, who criticized Robeson’s support of Soviet Russia. Branch Rickey helped this man accomplish his most notable goal.

This other organization denounced Robeson’s comments in an effort to maintain a moderate public image. Robeson was criticized in this organization’s newspaper The Crisis, which was founded by W.E.B. DuBois.
answers_formatted: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People [or NAACP]

parts: Name this queer theorist, the author of The Queer Art of Failure, who also used Spongebob and Dory from Finding Nemo to outline his theory of Gaga Feminism.

In Female Masculinity, Halberstam discussed how "the bathroom problem," arises from the binary of this concept. This concept is distinct from sex, as it considers cultural and presentational aspects in addition to biology.

Many queer theorists trace their work back to this book by Michel Foucault. This book refutes the "repressive hypothesis" of its title subject and contains the volumes The Use of Pleasure, The Care of Self, and Confessions of the Flesh.
answers_formatted: The History of Sexuality [or L'Histoire de la sexualité]

FORTRAN makes use of the intrinsic data type, character, to store this kind of data typically denoted by quotation marks. In Java, a plus sign is used to concatenate two of these data types, which represent text.

parts: Name this author whose namesake “controversy” in the mid-20th century criticizes his rhetorical flourishes and asks why he gave the villain of his most famous work all the best lines.
Lucifer rules over Hell in this epic poem, John Milton’s magnum opus.
When talking to his companion Beelzelbub, Lucifer says it is “Better to reign in Hell than” do this three-word phrase.

bonuses.leadin: The introduction of this type of work to Spanish painting is credited to the Toledo-born painter Blas de Prado after his travels to the Court of Morocco. For 10 points each:
answers: El Escorial [Monasterio de El Escorial or Royal Monastery of San Lorenzo El Real]
parts: Name this type of work. Austere, realistic works of this type in their bodegón genre were created by de Prado’s student, Juan Sanchez Cotán, and included common pantry items among other elements like fruits and bowls.

This later Spanish painter created many still-lives influenced by the earlier works of Cotán. The title Mercedarian Saint slumps his head and dies with arms bound to a tree by ropes in his Martyrdom of Saint Serapion.
In addition to introducing the still life genre, de Prado was also a prominent painter for Philip II while housed at this monastery and palace designed by Juan Bautista de Toledo northwest of Madrid.
answers_formatted: El Escorial [Monasterio de El Escorial or Royal Monastery of San Lorenzo El Real]

bonuses.leadin: Members of this empire’s first dynasty venerated Virupaksha as their family deity and built their capital city around that deity’s traditional cult center. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this empire first ruled by the Sangama Dynasty. This empire’s decline was hastened by their defeat at the Battle of Talikota.

Under the Sangama dynasty, the Vijayanagara frequently came into conflict with the Bhamani Sultanate, whose military were renowned for their superiority with these animals. Import of these animals from the steppes of central Europe was vital to the Vijayanagara military expansion of the 16th century.

The collapse of the Vijayanagara came at the hands of a Sultanate from this factional south Indian region surrounded by the Ghat mountains. Tippu Sultan would later lead the Mysore kingdom from this plateau region.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about one of the most prestigious awards in the film industry: the MTV Movie Award for Best Kiss. For 10 points each:
answers: To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before
parts: This actor won the 2006 award for his kiss with Jake Gyllenhaal in the cowboy romance Brokeback Mountain. He won a posthumous Oscar for playing the Joker in The Dark Knight.
The 2019 award went to Lana Condor and Noah Centineo for their kiss in this romantic comedy about Lara Jean, whose secret letters confessing her love to her crushes are mailed out by her sister.
The first-ever award went to Anna Chlumsky and a pre-Home Alone Macaulay Culkin for this 1991 film, in which Culkin’s character dies from an allergic reaction caused by bee stings.
answers_formatted: To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before
acceptable: To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before
To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before

bonuses.leadin: The protein POT1 and the “shelterin” complex protect these structures by binding to their characteristic TTAGGG repeats and stabilizing their displacement loop. For 10 points each:
answers: breakage-fusion-bridge cycle(s) [accept BFB cycle; prompt on partial answers]
anaphase [accept anaphase bridge(s) or anaphase promoting complex; prompt on APC]
parts: Name these structures at the ends of chromosomes whose shortening over time is linked to the Hayflick limit and cellular senescence.

Barbara McClintock discovered this process in which telomere erosion at the end of chromosomes prompts the unprotected ends to join together, split unevenly, and create chaotic, nonhomologous chromosomes during mitosis.

One characteristic of breakage-fusion-bridge cycles are centromeric “bridges” named for this phase of mitosis. An E3 ubiquitin ligase complex that targets cell cycle proteins for degradation is named for “promoting” this phase of mitosis.
answers_formatted: anaphase [accept anaphase bridge(s) or anaphase promoting complex; prompt on APC]

bonuses.leadin: Nardwuar the Human Serviette asked this man a question about pepper spraying protesters, to which this man evasively responded, “for me, I put pepper on my plate.” For ten points each:
answers: Jean Chretien [accept Joseph Jacques Jean Chretien]
Kim Campbell [or Avril Phaedra Douglas Campbell]
parts: Name this world leader whose other awkward interactions with civilians include a time when he put Bill Clennett in a chokehold.
To become prime minister, Chretien defeated this predecessor, who mocked him with an ad about his Bell’s Palsy. This first female Canadian prime minister served only for a few months in 1993.

Campbell’s predecessor, Brian Mulroney, attempted to get this province to agree to the Meech Lake Accords. A failed 1995 referendum for this province’s independence prompted Jacques Parizeau to blame it on “money and the ethnic vote.”

bonuses.leadin: One of America’s “Big Five” publishers is the “Book Group” division of this company. For 10 points each:
answers: George Sand [or Amandine Aurore Lucille Dupin]
parts: Name this largest publishing company in France. Its logo is the letter H.
This author left his job as head of publicity of Hachette after the publication of his novel La Confession de Claude. He is better known for writing the novel Germinal and the open letter J’accuse.
Hachette’s founder, Louis Hachette, sold books written by this author, who adopted a male pseudonym for her novel Indiana. Her novel A Winter of Majorca is about a trip she took with Frederic Chopin.

bonuses.leadin: Works in this form that continue perpetually, such as “Row, Row, Row Your Boat,” are called rounds. For 10 points each:
answers: prolation canon [or mensuration canon, or proportional canon]
augmentation [or canon by augmentation; or augmented canon; or augmented interval; accept sloth canon]
parts: Name this type of contrapuntal piece where one voice states a melody that is then repeated by the other voices. Johann Pachelbel wrote one of these pieces “in D” that is often played at weddings.
Johannes Ockeghem wrote an entire mass consisting of this type of canon in which accompanying voices play the main melody at different tempi.

If the accompanying voice doubles the rhythmic value of the main melody, thereby singing at half the speed, the prolation canon is known by this term. This term can also be used to describe an interval made by raising a perfect or major interval by a half step.
answers_formatted: augmentation [or canon by augmentation; or augmented canon; or augmented interval; accept sloth canon]

bonuses.leadin: The first of this figure's labors occurs in Epidaurus when a son of Hephaestus and Anticlea is beaten to death with his own bronze club. For ten points each:
parts: Name this hero, whose other accomplishments involved pushing Sciron off of a cliff and into the mouth of a turtle and ripping Sinis apart with tree branches.

Another of Theseus' labors involved killing this king of Eleusis, who would challenge travelers to wrestling matches. This king ordered his daughter Alope to be buried alive when he discovered she had given birth to Hipothoon after she was raped by Poseidon.

Theseus is most famous for killing the Minotaur, which he accomplished with the help of this daughter of Minos. After Theseus abandoned this woman on Naxos, Dionysus rescued and eventually married her.
